p: In Tanzania, dengue outbreaks have been reported repeatedly in 2010, 2012 [ 28– 30], 2013 and 2014 [ 31]. The most important vector in Tanzania is Ae. aegypti which is found in urban environments and prefers feeding on humans and the virus circulation is maintained through transovarial transmission [ 24, 32]. Ae. aegypti usually bites in shady areas during the day or when the weather is cloudy, but biting is significantly high two hours after sunrise and before sunset [ 33]. Transmission of DENV to humans by mosquitoes involves complex processes influenced by mosquito genetics, viral genetics and bioclimatic factors [ 34]. The climatic conditions in which the immature mosquito larvae develop have a particularly large influence on the viral susceptibility and transmission capability of adult female mosquitoes [ 35– 37].
